outcome_measure: Smartphone PVT reaction time (5-min) after night shift
outcome_timepoint: First night shift of each schedule (Table 2)
effect_size_reported: First shift PVT RT: 0.67 s (morning sleep) vs 0.55 s (evening sleep), p=0.001; adjusted p=0.015 (Table 2). Lapses: 18.5 vs 15.4, p=0.009; adjusted p=0.115.

outcome_timepoint: end of each 2-month condition (mixed model treatment effect estimate)
effect_size_reported: Treatment effect estimate -28.36 ms (95% CI -47.48, -9.23), t=-2.91, d=-1.75, p=.004; n=18 for PVT.

outcome_timepoint: end of each 2-month condition (mixed model treatment effect estimate)
effect_size_reported: Treatment effect estimate -15.10 ms (95% CI -25.03, -5.16), t=-2.98, d=-2.98, p=.003; n=18 for PVT.

outcome_timepoint: Case 2 only: baseline, mid/end treatment, mid/end control
effect_size_reported: Case 2 PVT mean RT (ms): 310.44 (baseline) -> 300.03 (mid T) -> 314.75 (end T) -> 288.65 (mid C) -> 268.51 (end C) (Table 2).

outcome_measure: PVT median reaction speed (1/RT) (10-min), by time awake
outcome_timepoint: Post-night-shift lab visit (daytime sleep schedule), across wake period
effect_size_reported: Median reaction speed: no main effect of adaptation group (p=0.88); main effect of visit (p=0.012); main effect of time awake (p=0.036); 3-way interaction (group×visit×time-awake) p=0.046. During visit 2, adapted group faster than non-adapted after 8–14h awake (p≤0.045).

outcome_timepoint: Day-shift afternoon break (~14:00-15:00), repeated measures; subset n=11
effect_size_reported: Estimated mean RT: 264 ms (non-BL) vs 235.8 ms (BL); diff -28.2 ms (95% CI -46.2, -10.2), F(1,17.0)=11.0, p<0.01 (Table 4).

outcome_timepoint: Day-shift afternoon break; subset n=11

outcome_measure: PVT reaction time / reaction speed (10-min; PVT-192)
outcome_timepoint: Monday afternoon after the weekend (post-intervention vs post-control weekend)
effect_size_reported: Significantly shorter reaction times on Mondays after the intervention vs habitual weekend sleep (p<0.05); overall condition×day interaction F(3,175)=6.01, p=0.001 (Figure 3; Table 1).

outcome_timepoint: Monday afternoon after the weekend
effect_size_reported: Fewer PVT lapses on Mondays after intervention vs habitual weekend sleep (p<0.05); overall condition×day interaction F(3,175)=4.53, p=0.004 (Figure 3; Table 1).

outcome_timepoint: Thursday afternoon after the weekend
effect_size_reported: Significantly longer reaction times on Thursdays after intervention vs habitual weekend sleep (p<0.05), despite Monday improvement; condition×day interaction F(3,175)=6.01, p=0.001 (Figure 3; Table 1).

outcome_timepoint: Thursday afternoon after the weekend
effect_size_reported: Significantly more lapses on Thursdays after intervention vs habitual weekend sleep (p<0.05); condition×day interaction F(3,175)=4.53, p=0.004 (Figure 3; Table 1).

outcome_measure: Objective 5-min serial reaction-time test (Palm) at 3 timepoints during shifts
outcome_timepoint: Nights 1,3,6 and days 1,3,6
effect_size_reported: No significant differences in reaction times when averaged across night shift or day shift. Day shift showed condition×day interaction F(4,44)=4.1, p=0.025 (Table 1), driven by increased reaction times on day 1 after melatonin and bright light (narrative; Figure 4).

outcome_timepoint: multiple times during shifts; compared across conditions and across shift hours
effect_size_reported: PVT performance comparable regardless of intervention; neither experimental nor active placebo altered PVT (Fig 6). Median RT increased across the night shift when averaged across interventions (p=0.007).

outcome_timepoint: Daily across confinement (reported comparisons day 3/4 vs day 8)
effect_size_reported: Reaction time decreased on day 3 (practice effect; p=0.050) then increased day-by-day; day 8 reaction time significantly longer than day 3 (p=0.026) and day 4 (p=0.016). Error counts increased trend but not significant.

outcome_measure: Test of Attentional Performance (TAP) Alertness subtest: reaction time (ms)
outcome_timepoint: Pre vs post 12-week intervention; group x time interaction

outcome_measure: PVT (10-min) at beginning and end of each night shift
outcome_timepoint: Across four consecutive night shifts per condition
effect_size_reported: Abstract reports no differences in alertness between conditions in summer or winter study (no effect sizes/p-values provided in abstract).

outcome_timepoint: Across baseline vs sleep restriction vs recovery (time-on-task analysis)
effect_size_reported: Authors report RTs deteriorate during sleep restriction vs baseline and return to baseline during recovery (Table 1 summary: BASE->SR yes (increase); SR->RCV yes (decrease); full return).

outcome_timepoint: Across baseline vs sleep restriction vs recovery
effect_size_reported: Accuracy decreases during sleep restriction and only partially returns during recovery (Table 1 summary: BASE->SR yes (decrease); SR->RCV partial (increase)).

outcome_timepoint: Baseline + weeks 1-4; plus 1-week follow-up
effect_size_reported: Group×session interaction: mean RT F(4,144)=2.59, p<0.05, partial η²=0.07 (increase across weeks only in BLB). Follow-up (BLB only): baseline vs week4 vs follow-up F(2,36)=21.79, p<0.001, partial η²=0.55; baseline vs follow-up ns (reversible).

outcome_timepoint: Baseline vs week4 vs follow-up (BLB only)
effect_size_reported: Baseline-weekly group×session for omissions not significant (p=0.25), but BLB baseline vs week4 vs follow-up differed: omission errors F(2,36)=5.15, p<0.05, partial η²=0.22 (post-hoc: baseline vs week4 and week4 vs follow-up significant; baseline vs follow-up ns).

outcome_timepoint: Across shifts; light×time interaction
effect_size_reported: No light main effect overall (EMM 257.99 vs 259.24 ms; p=0.283), but light×time interaction significant: F(4,807)=2.91, p=0.021; post-hoc differences at later night timepoints (Figure 4; stars at ~04:00 and 05:30).

outcome_timepoint: Late night (05:30) during shifts
effect_size_reported: Light×time effect: fewer false starts at 05:30 with 7000K vs 2500K: EMM 3.33 (SE 0.57) vs 4.83 (SE 0.93), p=0.040 (reported in results; Figure 3D).

outcome_measure: Psychomotor Vigilance Task (PVT): 10% slowest reaction times (log-transformed)
outcome_timepoint: Day 2; mixed model across time since scheduled wake (7h and 11h); post-hoc at 11h since wake
effect_size_reported: Main effect condition F(1,18)=3.5, p=0.04; condition x time-since-wake interaction F(1,18)=6.6, p=0.02; misalignment slower particularly at 11h since scheduled wake (post-hoc p<0.05).

outcome_timepoint: Day 2; mixed model across time since scheduled wake (7h and 11h)
effect_size_reported: Main effect condition F(1,18)=7.3, p=0.02; condition x time-since-wake interaction F(1,18)=15.4, p=0.001; more lapses under misalignment, particularly later in wake episode.

outcome_measure: Digit Symbol Substitution Test (DSST): correct responses per minute
outcome_timepoint: Day 2; mixed model across time since scheduled wake (5h,7h,9h,11h)
effect_size_reported: No main effect condition (F(1,46)=0.1, p=0.33), but condition x time interaction F(1,46)=6.6, p=0.01; DSST improved over time only under alignment (post-hoc at 11h p<0.05).

outcome_measure: Unstable Tracking Task (TKT): number of losses (log-transformed)
outcome_timepoint: Day 2; mixed model across time since scheduled wake (5h,7h,9h,11h)
effect_size_reported: Main effect condition F(1,40)=4.4, p=0.04; condition x time interaction F(1,46)=10.6, p=0.002; losses increased under misalignment beyond 7h since wake (post-hoc p<0.05).

outcome_timepoint: Day+night during 43h lab protocol (mixed model)
effect_size_reported: More lapses during withdrawal vs placebo/caffeine: main effect condition F(2,51)=6.66, p=0.0027; mean±SD (z) placebo -0.18±0.77, caffeine -0.09±1.04, withdrawal 0.27±1.11; post-hoc withdrawal>both p<0.01.

outcome_timepoint: Pre (S1) vs post (S2) MBT (ANCOVA with attendance covariate)
effect_size_reported: Session effect F(1,34)=10.571, p=0.003, eta_p^2=0.237; average RS decreased (S1 median 2.97 (SD 0.29) vs S2 median 2.86 (SD 0.28)). Attendance correlated with RS change r=0.322, p=0.055 (higher attendance = less decline).

outcome_timepoint: Pre vs post MBT (ANCOVA with attendance covariate)
effect_size_reported: Session effect F(1,33)=6.177, p=0.018, eta_p^2=0.158; lapses increased on average (S1 mean 7.60 (SD 3.45) vs S2 mean 8.94 (SD 7.16)). Attendance correlated with lapse change r=-0.348, p=0.04 (higher attendance = fewer lapses).

outcome_measure: Response inhibition accuracy (perceptual sensitivity A) on 32-min RIT sustained attention/response inhibition task
outcome_timepoint: Retreat 1: pre/mid/post; plus follow-ups (6 mo, 1.5y, 7y); growth-curve parameters
effect_size_reported: Growth model (retreat 1 training participants): linear training effect +0.126 (SE 0.017), p<0.01; quadratic training^2 -0.045 (SE 0.008), p<0.01 (Table 2). Authors report improvements during intensive practice partially maintained several years later, moderated by continued practice.

outcome_timepoint: Retreat training + years since retreat (YSR) follow-up slope
effect_size_reported: RTCV decreased during training: linear training -0.0125 (SE 0.004), p<0.01; RTCV increased across years since retreat: linear YSR +0.056 (SE 0.018), p<0.01 (Table 2).

outcome_measure: Psychomotor Vigilance Test (PVT; 5-min): mean reaction time (ms)
outcome_timepoint: Pre vs post sleep extension block (start vs end of 3-week intervention)
effect_size_reported: Mean RT 228.8±24.5 ms (pre) -> 220.0±18.4 (post); reported change -4.3% (±3.1%).

outcome_timepoint: Pre vs post sleep extension block
Pre vs post sleep extension block
effect_size_reported: Slowest 10% time 3.0±0.5 (pre) -> 3.3±0.5 (post); authors report moderate increase (11.7% ±7.2%).

outcome_timepoint: Baseline (non-habitual; >=24h abstinent), 30 min post ~250 mg caffeine

outcome_measure: Auditory reaction time (ms), high pitched stimulus (ART-H)
outcome_timepoint: Baseline (non-habitual; >=24h abstinent), 30 min post ~250 mg caffeine
After ~6 months daily coffee (200-600 mg/day), 30 min post ~250 mg caffeine

outcome_measure: Auditory reaction time (ms), high pitched stimulus (ART-H)
outcome_timepoint: After ~6 months daily coffee (200-600 mg/day), 30 min post ~250 mg caffeine
Baseline vs post sleep extension (assessment time not specified)
effect_size_reported: Mean reaction time unchanged: 302.7 +/- 20.2 ms -> 302.8 +/- 23.5 ms; p=0.98 (Table 10).

exposure_duration_days: ~21-35 (5 sessions described as weekly; exact calendar duration not fully specified)
outcome_timepoint: Pre vs post (post measured 1 week after final training)
effect_size_reported: Training group improved: 103.8 (34.68) -> 150.4 (36.70); p=0.003; effect size r^2=0.63. Authors report control showed no improvements.

outcome_measure: Sternberg short-term memory test: response time (ms)
outcome_timepoint: Pre vs post (post measured 1 week after final training)
effect_size_reported: Training group response time decreased: 1853.47 (503.64) ms -> 1397.09 (164.70) ms; p=0.007; effect size r^2=0.56.

outcome_timepoint: Across 7-day restriction + 5-day recovery (growth model; group x phase-slope interactions)
effect_size_reported: Habitual group deteriorated faster during restriction vs extended (RESTRICT x Group coef=0.40, SE=0.17, t=2.35, p=0.01, one-tailed). During recovery, extended recovered rapidly and stabilized while habitual improved gradually (RECOV x Group coef=-0.75, SE=0.39, t=-1.94, p=0.03, one-tailed).

outcome_timepoint: Post acute caffeine challenge (0-120 min summary)
effect_size_reported: 4CRT improved by 0.02±0.01 s after caffeine in both caffeine-naive and caffeine-replete conditions; no between-condition difference reported (authors: cognitive performance not affected by prior exposure).
